item.title: An FRP implementation in Haskell
item.description: Audience: This post is for meant for people familiar with Haskell, Classic style Functional Reactive Programming, and Reflex FRP in particular. I’ve been dissecting Reflex’ Spider implementation, so I’m sharing how to implement a similar library in a series of blog posts. In this first post I’ll focus on a simple implementation that is sufficiently lazy for typical recursive FRP definitions to work. However, it’s completely unoptimized and not garbage collected so that it can’t be used for real applications yet.
